Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Project - SFS CB: Establishing the New Mexico Digital Forensics Academy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is establishing a permanent digital forensics program at Western New Mexico University (WNMU) in collaboration with Auburn University. It is providing a statewide digital forensics resource that currently does not exist in New Mexico. WNMU?s unique combined mission of regional community college as well as regional university provides unique opportunities to explore program integration with New Mexico 2-year law enforcement programs. Deliverables from this project include:

1. Establish an 18-hour minor in digital forensics as part of the WNMU undergraduate and graduate Criminal Justice programs.
2. Establish an 18-hour graduate certificate program in digital forensics as part of the WNMU Criminal Justice program.
3. Establish an advanced digital forensics training program for New Mexico law enforcement.
4. Conduct Regional workshops for diverse audiences drawn from New Mexico state and local law enforcement agencies as well as students from other campuses.

The intellectual challenge for this project is to determine how a small university in a remote corner of a large state can develop, deliver and sustain a technically challenging digital forensics program across a large state. The project is assessing courses learning outcomes as well as elements such as the practicality of course contents, the way the contents is delivered, the lab environment and setup, the effectiveness of projects and assignments, lab assistance quality and inclusion/exclusion suggestions for course contents and projects.

This first of its kind program in New Mexico enjoys broad support from the state government. This ensures a broad impact across the state. This program could serve as a model for other underserved states, particularly large, rural states.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome Report for
Establishing the New Mexico Digital Forensics Academy

The project resulted in the development and implementation of the first and currently only digital forensics program in the State of New Mexico at Western New Mexico University (WNMU), an HSI.    

As described at:  http://behavioral.wnmu.edu/cjus/digital-forensics/ “An 18-credit hour minor or certificate program provides training for law enforcement personnel in digital forensics; and outreach programs to ordinary citizens to make them aware of the various types of cyber-crimes and how to prevent victimization.”

This minor is offered for undergraduate criminal justice majors and as a graduate certificate for WNMU students in the interdisciplinary studies department.    NSF enabled the development of four new three-hour 400/500 level courses:

  • MIS/CJUS 425/525 Digital Forensics I 
  • MIS/CJUS 426/526 Digital Forensics II 
  • CJUS 457/557 Forensic Law
  • CJUS 401/501 Introduction to Information Security

Digital Forensics I and II are cross-listed in management information systems as well as criminal justice.  NSF also enabled the revitalization of a computer science course that was no longer being taught:  CMPS 440/540 Information Warfare.

Because of the support received from NSF, we helped WNMU build demand for criminal justice through outreach.  Specifically, we conducted the following outreach activities:

11-15 August 2014, we taught Basic Digital Forensics at WMNU (Silver City, NM). 5 people registered, 3 attended the course.  In January 2015, we taught Basic Digital Forensics in Santa Fe, NM at the NM Law Enforcement Academy (NMLEA) with 17 students. Note that the New Mexico Law Enforcement Academy only requires class attendance for continuing education credit from NMLEA. Students were given the choice to accomplish a final exam to receive course credit from WMNU. 3 students elected to do this. Since WNMU charges tuition for this, most participants did not seek course credit.

31 August - 4 September 2015, performers taught Advanced Digital Forensics at the University of New Mexico (UNM-Albuquerque, NM). 48 registered. 43 attended the first day. 26 completed the course. 2 students from WMNU will complete the exit exam for college credit. 9 UNM students will receive credit from UNM.

Our external reviewer, Dr. Martin Carlisle, reviewed feedback for the 31 August - 4 September 2015 course. In general, students indicated that their knowledge improved during the course. They also indicated the content and presentation were good. There were issues with the lab equipment at UNM (the number of students enrolled exceeded the laptops provided by the grant, so they used computers at UNM).

Three 40 hour seminars taught in Silver City, NM, Santa Fe, NM and Albuquerque NM as described in the key outcomes section.

The results have been disseminated to communities of interest via the web page at: http://web.cse.msstate.edu/~hamilton/Forensics/

Faculty at WNMU had a strong passion to use this effort to reach out to working cyber security professionals in the state who were stranded in the middle of their degree programs when the for-profit IIT Tech suddenly shut down.  MSU collaborated with WNMU to help them put together a three-hour course offered via distance based on ISC2’s Certified Information Systems Security Professional Review Course.  The 1700+ slides of this course can found at: http://web.cse.msstate.edu/~hamilton/P3I/CISSP/ .

Because NSF-funded this effort, New Mexico has its first digital forensics program positioned to serve one of the most remote and underserved regions in the country. 

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2017
Modified by: John A Hamilton

Because NSF-funded this effort, New Mexico has its first digital forensics program positioned to serve one of the most remote and underserved regions in the country.
